UI_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire according to one interpretation, where the individual characters don't seem to matter very much1. It also serves as a microcosm of society, providing a profound examination of how individuals and communities respond to an unprecedented crisis6. Additionally, it has been described as a science-fiction/fantasy series that explores the dark side of humans in captivity7. The story involves a small town that is suddenly sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome, which aligns with its classification as a science fiction drama8.
traffic_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire according to one interpretation, where the individual characters don't seem to matter very much [[1]]. It also serves as a microcosm of society, providing a profound examination of how individuals and communities respond to an unprecedented crisis [[6]]. Additionally, it has been described as a science-fiction/fantasy series that explores the dark side of humans in captivity [[7]]. The story involves a small town that is suddenly sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome, which aligns with its classification as a science fiction drama [[8]].
